B00005JNJT|4.0|The most entertaining and conventional movie of the \\"Batman\\" series, Christopher Nolan's \\"Batman Begins\\" seeks to create a launching pad for new slew of Caped Crusader films, and this origin story, while choppy and imperfect, sets the buffet table. Here's report card of the movie's strengths and weaknesses, something to differentiate this review from others: <br /> <br />STRENGTHS: <br /> <br />THE APPROACH - No Marc Chagall nightmare worlds. No zany gay chic. Nolan (\\"Insomnia\\" and \\"Memento\\") and screenwriter David S. Goyer bring realism - considering it worked so well in \\"Spider-Man\\" series - back into the fold. Gotham is a slightly futuristic, burned-out New York. But we can still recognize it; the movie's most glorious shot is of Batman high atop Wayne Tower, looking down upon a candyland of city lights. No special f/x - just a gorgeous shot of a man above his city. \\"Batman Begins\\" has an amount of restraint to it. <br /> <br />THE SCREENPLAY:  Short on one-liners and ominous phrases, long character development and serious talk. Even the Burton \\"Batman\\" movies had a lot invested in being funny; Goyer and Nolan are content to use the natural humor of Christian Bale and trust audience to pay attention, not wait to be entertained.  <br /> <br />CHRISTIAN BALE: Here's the edgy \\"Batman\\" they've been looking for. Bale's played enough villain roles - \\"American Psycho,\\" \\"Shaft\\" - to approach the anti-hero a swirl of swagger, anger, conviction and droll humor. Physically, Bale surpasses Keaton, Kilmer and Clooney. As an actor, he's less mysterious than Keaton - and a little less believable a billionaire tycoon, too - and his \\"tough\\" voice - well, it sounds a little forced. Still - right guy. Fine pick. <br /> <br />ORIGIN STORY: Wayne is investigating the nature of evil in a Chinese prison when his mentor, Ducard (Liam Neeson), rescues and invites him to a training facility in the Himalayas. Ducard teaches him the dark arts, and extracts the story of Bruce's childhood. There are nice touches about bats, the death of his parents, Bruce's planned revenge against his their murderer. Ducard invites Bruce into the League of Shadows, led by Ra's Al Ghul (Ken Watanabe). The League wants to go a little farther than Bruce is willing to. Bruce declines their offer in violent fashion, returns to Gotham, and, with butler Alfred (Michael Caine) and Wayne Enterprises scientist Lucius Fox (Morgan Freeman. The \\"origin\\" material is always a little slow - and the cross-cutting between training and Bruce's childhood is a bit annoying, but \\"X-Men\\" and \\"Spider-Man\\" both survived these growing pains for excellent sequels.  <br /> <br />MICHAEL CAINE AND MORGAN FREEMAN: Old pros. Instant credibility.  <br /> <br />GARY OLDMAN AS SGT. GORDON: Finally, a Gordon who's not a caricature or a punchline. Oldman plays him simply as a decent, honest cop, one of the few left in Gotham, and Batman's first partner. The role isn't overplayed, but Gordon does more than just proclaim and stand around - he's shoehorned nicely into the climax. <br /> <br />VILLAINS: Not unforgettable. Just not stupid. It makes sense that the first criminal worth fighting is simply mob boss Carmine Falcone (Tom Wilkinson). Ducard/Ra's Al Ghul is a thinking man's villain, and The League of Shadows are pretty faceless but not cartoonish. Cillian Murphy is funny/creepy as Dr. Johnathan Crane/The Scarecrow, but he doesn't have much to do. \\"Batman Begins\\" is focused more on the Bat than it is his tormentors, as it should be, because these villains likely won't roll around again.  <br /> <br />MUSICAL SCORE: By Howard Shore and James Newton Howard. Never intrudes, usually enhances. During the \\"money shot\\" scene - that one atop Gotham - it's quiet and grand. <br /> <br />LEAGUE OF SHADOWS INITIATION: Mysterious and unpredictable, Nolan shot and edited this sequence more for the idea being enclosed by 30 deadly assassins than clarity. Suspenseful.  <br /> <br />WEAKNESSES <br /> <br />KATIE HOLMES:  Her Rachel Dawes, childhood friend of Bruce Wayne and gritty Gotham prosecutor, is a grim one, a stick in the mud who talks at length about doing justice without accomplishing much. In this day and age, is a lawyer really a symbol of virtue? Holmes isn't in the movie much, the romance is downplayed, but her character wears a rather unfortunate silk blouse in the movie's second-to-last scene.  <br /> <br />CONTINUITY: At times \\"Batman Begins\\" strikes me as cobbled together in parts. The beginning is especially jagged, though necessarily so. The plot is a little too jammed, though: Rutger Hauer has no purpose as the de facto head of Wayne Enterprises - unless he figures into the sequel. Rachel's boss disappears without much fanfare. Falcone, the mob boss, goes off the map halfway through the picture.  <br /> <br />BATMOBILE CHASE: The vehicle itself - cross a Hummer and the design of a B-2 Stealth Bomber - is interesting. The chase through Gotham, more than ten minutes long, is blah.  <br /> <br />ACTION SCENE AT THE DOCKS: Again. Blah.  <br /> <br />CLIMACTIC ACTION SCENE: On an elevated train at night. Not nearly as effective as a similiar scene in \\"Spider-Man.\\" Anti-climactic and, since it's in the dark of night, not exactly thrilling.  <br /> <br />VILLAINOUS PLOT TO DESTROY GOTHAM: It's a blatant steal from the original \\"Batman!\\" Chemicals combining with other chemicals. Deadly gases. A poisoned populace.  <br /> <br />Overall, \\"Batman Begins\\" takes on a bigger assignment than its predecessors and passes, well. The franchise is built to last with a grounding in semi-reality and four excellent actors - Bale, Oldman, Caine and Freeman - to carry it for a couple more films. Nolan, should he continue, will get a bigger budget to play with a splashy villain and maybe a more interesting female lead than Holmes, who is pretty and upstanding but a bit of a bore.

B0000640VN|2.0|Or maybe not.<br /><br />At first, the romantic comedy Kate & Leopold seems like an odd film for James Mangold to direct in between the teenager-in-an-asylum movie Girl, Interrupted and the slasher-horror film Identity. Mangold's other movies (like Cop Land) are more noirish than cute, too.<br /><br />But Kate & Leopold does have one thing in common with Girl, Interrupted and Identity - - one of the main characters is in a mental institution. Stuart, an inventor and Kate's old boyfriend, is locked up when he says he's discovered a crack in time that permits travel to 1876. Stuart also says the man staying in his apartment is an English duke who came back with him from 1876. Of course Kate and Leopold fall in love.<br /><br />It's too bad Leopold couldn't have found a way to stay with Kate in the twenty-first century. Kate and Leopold both make a physical leap (off the Brooklyn Bridge, which is just over the time portal Stuart discovered), but Leopold jumps back to a familiar world. Kate gives up her family and her career. Leopold is also an inventor and an educated aristocrat and would have more opportunities in Kate's time than Kate would as a woman in his. (\\"Research is a fine profession for a woman. Suitable to the feminine mind.\\")<br /><br />Many reviewers of this movie have noticed that Kate chooses the traditional role, picking a man over a life. But Leopold is more afraid of the new than Kate, and by going back to 1876 Leopold takes the easy way out. Just like Kate, Leopold's choice limits his possibilities (but not to the same extent as Kate's).<br /><br />Leopold has already invented the elevator in his own time, inspired by the \\"erections\\" (I hope Mangold is ashamed of the childish jokes in the first scene) being built in 1876. During his time in the twenty-first century he even invents an improved toaster. For Leopold to go back and miss out on what the new age has to offer is just as cowardly as Kate trying to be the heroine in one of her assistant's romance novels instead of living in the real world.<br /><br />We don't see much of 1876 society except for a grand ball at Leopold's uncle's mansion, which is good, because the poverty and racism in the time Leopold came from might spoil our fantasy. When a black female New York cop tells Leopold to pick up dog poop, his reaction is respectful, admirable, and completely unbelievable. Leopold accepts the social differences between his time and ours too easily.<br /><br />The DVD has the original theatrical release and the director's cut. The director's cut makes a few of the time-travel twists more understandable. The director's cut tells us that Leopold is Stuart's ancestor, which is why Leopold has to get back to 1876, otherwise Stuart won't be born. That also makes Stuart, who has just broken up with Kate, someone who (assuming Kate and Leopold live happily ever after) has been sleeping with his great-great-something grandmother. The producers might have thought that was a little too Sophoclean for the theatrical release.<br /><br />If you want to see a dumb romantic comedy that doesn't leave a taste in your mouth like Farmer's Bounty (the \\"raw suet\\" margarine Leopold winds up being TV spokesman for), check out Wimbledon or One Fine Day.stant's romance novels instead of living in the real world. <br /> <br />We don't see much of 1876 society except for a grand ball at Leopold's uncle's mansion, which is good, because the poverty and racism in the time Leopold came from might spoil our fantasy. When a black female New York cop tells Leopold to pick up dog poop, his reaction is respectful, admirable, and completely unbelievable. Leopold accepts the social differences between his time and ours too easily.   <br /> <br />The DVD has the original theatrical release and the director's cut. The director's cut makes a few of the time-travel twists more understandable. The director's cut tells us that Leopold is Stuart's ancestor, which is why Leopold has to get back to 1876, otherwise Stuart won't be born. That also makes Stuart, who has just broken up with Kate, someone who (assuming Kate and Leopold live happily ever after) has been sleeping with his great-great-something grandmother. The producers might have thought that was a little too Sophoclean for the theatrical release. <br /> <br />If you want to see a dumb romantic comedy that doesn't leave a taste in your mouth like Farmer's Bounty (the \\"raw suet\\" margarine Leopold winds up being TV spokesman for), check out Wimbledon or One Fine Day.  <br /> <br />

B000002BFL|4.0|This quiet sequel to 1982's \\"Nebraska\\" came two years into the Clinton administration just as the country was recovering from the Reagan era and before the boom that would define the end of the decade. The actors on \\"The Ghost of Tom Joad\\" seem to have it no better in the mid-90's and these songs focus on the same loss, betrayal, and despair that tinted \\"Nebraska\\". It highlights the unfortunate reality that drastic change in the human condition isn't easily achieved, and sure as hell isn't done quickly. So thirteen years later you still have the same type of wanderers who are still so lost and still only left to wonder why.  <br /> <br />The sparse musical landscape that houses these songs were meant to highlight the literary intensity of Springsteen's lyrics. This makes the words themselves the music (in fact they are so rich that they can be easily read and understood reading from the liner notes). And the album plays like a sort of short story collection, with every one loosely lending itself to it's overall theme. These extremely capable renderings do put into fine view it's veterans, homeless strangers, and drifters, and while these stories are being told you know you're hearing them the way they were meant to be heard. Albums like \\"The Ghost of Tom Joad\\" showcase Bruce Springsteen as one of the finest storytellers in rock & roll, and it also happens to be one of his best.  <br /> <br />STANDOUT TRACKS: 01- THE GHOST OF TOM JOAD, 02- STRAIGHT TIME 04- YOUNGSTOWN, 05- SINALOA COWBOYS  <br />

B00097DX3U|2.0|Audioslave's first album was fantastic and I consider it one of the best albums I've ever heard.  Needless to say, I was very excited to get Out of Exile, hoping that there would be more hard-edged, progressive songs.  Sadly, after playing it repeatedly, I grow more and more disappointed by it.  Now, this disappointment is making me angry.  How could this band produce such a formulaic, pop album after creating such music masterpieces as Bring Em Back Alive and Exploder?  Be Yourself is simply a copy of Like a Stone, complete with matching guitar solo.  And what in the world is that high singing part in Dandelion?  I cringe when I hear it because it's so syrupy.  #1 Zero is a copy of Soungarden's Tighter and Tighter that lacks any originality.  Also, does Yesterday and Tomorrow remind anyone of Pearl Jam's Jeremy?  And the final song on the album, The Curse, is such a formula pop rock ballad.  It's as if the song was written as a concert ender, where people can flick their bics and wave their hands in the air.  Yuck.  To judge this band's huge decline in originality, just compare The Curse to The Last Remaining Light, the brilliant and dark ending from the first album.      When I saw an interview on CNN a few weeks ago, Audioslave  members said they didn't really know each other on the first album.  They are feeling like a more integrated band now.  Well, that saddens me tremendously, because I miss the incredible progressive edge that Audioslave produced in 2002.  My husband speculates that Chris' substance abuse helped fuel the first album, as it did on Soundgarden's masterpieces, and now that he's clean, he's lost the need to be so heavy.  Gosh, Audioslave, can't you be sober and also write incredible songs?    This is very hard for me to write, since I so admire Chris Cornell and his musical and lyrical talent.  I hope that their next album isn't so trivial.
B0002YCVXI|4.0|Yo-Yo Ma is certainly one of the premiere cellists of today and his performances in the symphony concert halls and in chamber music concerts are always illuminating and impact audiences with the incredible skill and sonority of his chosen instrument.  Perhaps it is the 'Everyman' syndrome that encourages Ma to enter fields usually not taken by classical cellists, as though he wants to offer his talent for the appreciation of all audiences.  He has recorded Appalachian songs, Tangos, the oriental sounds of the Silk Road, and has been featured in movie sound tracks while still performing the full spectrum of the classical repertoire.  There can only be admiration for such intent.<br /><br />In this CD he has collaborated with renowned movie music composer Ennio Morricone creating transcriptions of the scores of such films as 'The Mission', 'Cinema Paradiso', 'The Legend of 1900', 'The Untouchables', 'The Good the Bad and the Ugly', 'Once Upon a Time in America' and others and the result is a series of 'cello concerti'.  Some of these work well (the excerpts form 'The Mission' are truly beautiful, but that was one of Morricone's finest scores in the first place), and some of them sound a bit like Muzak or elevator music.  Ma's playing is consistently elegant and lovely and if the content of Morricone's music is occasionally slight, then it must be remembered that this music was written as background music for visual dramas.<br /><br />The recording is not truly in the classical mode, just in case Ma's devoted fans may think this is going to be deep music.  But the collection is well executed and the music is never less than lovely.  With that in mind the CD can be generally recommended. Grady Harp, June 05

Definitely a buy!  Cuckoo ForCeltic <br />

B000002UA0|5.0|\\"Do you remember when you were young? You shone like the sun\\" - A memorable line from a memorable song. The song, entitled \\"Shine On, You Crazy Diamond\\" was a tribute piece, dedicated to the founder of Pink Floyd, and the creative drive behind this particular Pink Floyd album. His name is Syd Barrett, and he was the mind behind \\"The Piper at the Gates of Dawn\\". <br /> <br />The year was 1969, and pshycedelia was at an all-time high. Everybody seemed to enjoy trippy, colorful music that could give people out-of-this-world images. Syd Barrett was one of the most talented song-writers of his time, and he was able to give these kinds of qualities to his songs and more. Some people find this comparison extreme, but I feel that if John Lennon is the basis for song writing skills, Syd Barrett is his younger brother, the one who was never nearly as popular but made more artistic, and less-accessible work. <br /> <br />Barrett's only major album from Pink Floyd was filled with creatures, tales, and strange new musical innovations. He sang of gnomes, scare crows, Egyptian cats, out of control doctors, and planetary systems. The lyrics were playful but at the same time frightening. The instrumentals had a strange connectivity with the liquid singing. The words were carefully selected and used in a very fun and exciting English accent. The songs are written in a way that are extremely fitting for Syd Barrett's playing style. One reading just lyric sheets of this album may consider the lyrics junk, but when put to guitars, bass, keyboard, and drums, and with a pinch of Barrett's genius, they come to life. All of the sudden, nothing means something. All of the sudden, just ordinary phsychedelia becomes innovation. <br /> <br />\\"A movement is accomplished in six stages... and the seventh brings return\\". <br />\\"Doctor please kindly tell your wife that I\\"m alive! Realize! Realize! Realize!\\" <br />\\"And then one day, hurray, another way for gnomes to say, Oh My!\\" <br />\\"I've got a clan of gingerbread men - here are men, there are men, lots of gingerbread men - take a couple if you wish, they're on the dish\\" <br /> <br />One might ask what Syd was on when he was writing this music. Sadly, he was on LSD, and it completely destroyed his musical career and put him into a downward spiral that made him end up out of the band, living in isolation with only his mother in his home in Britain. However, due to Syd's short-lived career (releasing a total of three albums), Pink Floyd became one of the biggest, best, and most amazing bands to ever exist. Because of Barrett, and because of this album, psychedelic rock music became more than just trippy special effects and incoherent mumblings. It was a new way to incorporate very catchy (and eerily cheerful) music with very complex song structures, while still making it accessible to a large crowd. <br /> <br />Who can I recommend this album to? I will recommend it to anybody who has ever wanted to hear where Rock music's roots came from. I recommend this album to anybody who wants to hear some of the most creative and unique music from the late 60s era, and I recommend this album to all people out there who appreciate passionate creativity. This album was an amazing production, which lead to both greatness and misery, and both of those feelings are ones that you can share with Syd when experiencing this breakthrough work of art.
B00008WT5J|5.0|Even though it's not intentionally cut out to be an AC/DC compilation, it is technically a collection. Not entirely equipped with all (or even more) of their best songs, it is a good sampler, as well as a good soundtrack to a not-so-good movie. It's just too bad that AC/DC couldn't come up with at least 6 more new tracks to call it a 1986 full length album.  <br />The title track is probably my all-time favorite AC/DC song, because the music is catchy and Johnson sounds excellent. A more composed solo, and it would be a more perfect song. D.T. and Chase The Ace, are hard-rocking, fast-moving instrumentals which show how incredible the 4 instrument-playing members are. And, the rest of this album is classic AC/DC tunes used in the movie, and another chance to listen to them. The new (in 1986) version of Shake Your Foundations appears Brian Johnson to be sounding \\"not so far away\\" as his sound is on the Fly On The Wall album. It's not as long as the original version, but just as good. A good start or addition for any AC/DC fan upcoming or continuing.
B000683VI4|5.0|For myself this was one of those movies that is one of the great treats of being a fan: a film that comes along every so often and has you thinking that it's probably going to be pretty good but goes and blows away all expectations to stand as one of the elite.  In its opening minutes I thought it was actually going to fall below my initial expectations, as it took a few minutes to start to warm up to the Noah character (I liked Allie right from the start) but as things got going it just captivated me.  A rich, at times rather harrowing, very moving and sexy love story that incorporates dashes of comedy and mystery as well as eternally memorable moments popping up throughout.  Exceptionally done in every regard, with special kudos for the acting, photography and the gorgeous lighting capturing things like the sunrise on the lake - all this and great characterization make this a romantic drama that actually sits up there with the likes of \\"Ghost\\", \\"Millennium Actress\\" and \\"Titanic\\".  If you dip only occasionally into the drama section make sure this is one of the movies you check out.

B0000025T6|5.0|Powerful. Chilling. Beautiful. Moody. Sublime. Poignant. Masterful. Stark. Poetic. Heartwrenching. Funny. Raw. Minimalist. Subtle. Dangerous. Simply one of the greatest records I have ever heard.    <br />You could go on and on about this one. The cover photo to start with: Who would have the guts to put a b/w blurry photo, shot out of the windshield of a car on the front of a record? Why isn't it color? Where's the focus? Where are the people? Why no nice scenery? Not interested in any of that here! It works so wonderfully well, as does everything about this true masterpiece of an album. The record which showed what Springsteen was really all about.  <br />The stories, the people, the events he tells us about, they are so real. Mr. State Trooper: Please Don't Stop Me. You listen to that thing over and over again. The repetition of the bass chord of the acoustic guitar evoke the steady beat of rain and windshield wipers, the purring of an engine, traveling too fast in the night, on the run to or from--what? <br />Not really a song, more of a chant, it's a work of towering genius, one of the most evocative and transcendental things you could ever hear. He creates more with one guitar string and his own expressive voice than most musicians do with a full band.   <br />This is the opposite of a commercial release. It's the equivalent of a great black and white movie, which, let's face it, most people don't like to watch anymore. But it is so true that in many ways the black and white is more colorful, more truthful, more expressive than full, garish color. Think \\"In Cold Blood\\", \\"Red River\\", \\"The Seventh Seal\\", even \\"Sin City\\".  <br />This is about the only Springsteen album I listened to for years.  <br />Glad to see he is now doing an acoustic tour, which I would much more likely go to. Thanks
B000007T2Z|5.0|Maybe no one else will feel this way about this album simply because, perhaps, no one else quite came up with the same mental imagery as I did.  But it seems some people got the \\"end of the world\\" idea so I guess there are some who are close. <br /> <br />I was listening to this record at like 5 AM, just sitting in my room in the dark with only a sliver of dawn coming through.  I closed my eyes the whole time and....wow.  I've never listened to anything this dark and devastating.  No kiddies, Poison The Well, Slipknot and Cannibal Corpse are not dark and devastating, they are impotent morons who pose for the whiny and angsty 15-year-olds of America.  This, however.....THIS.....when I was listening to this, I almost clearly saw what the future armageddon looks like.  Dark clouds over a broken city with weary and dirty humans stumbling around the streets of rubble.  Standing on the edge of humanity as we know it was what I felt I was doing the whole time listening to this record.  Which leaves some issues people have brought up about it... <br /> <br />Experimental?  Pretentious?  Self-indulgent? <br /> <br />No.  This isn't Dream Theater, or Radiohead, or The Mars Volta.  This isn't pseudo-intellectual rock dripping with electronics and artificial lyrics to tell you how to feel.  Godspeed play natural, artistic music that comes almost entirely from the heart with just enough thought power to make it work.  Listen to this album and take a walk down the shattered streets, appreciating the last moment you'll ever get to see your lover.  Or perhaps it's the aftermath of destruction, and you are a survivor?  Board the train and watch the storm clouds quickly approach the skyline, or maybe stare at the face of a conductor who has lost his will to live and is simply doing his job out of primitive instinct.  What may seem like a glimmer of hope at first turns out only to be the sounds of a vacant carnival, or maybe a playground.  It's all up to you, really.  The tone of thealbum is laced in death and destruction, but it's your job to put in the pictures. <br /> <br />Godspeed You Black Emperor's \\"f#a#oo\\" doesn't demand that you wrap your head around some drawn-out concept or look for a hidden meaning around every corner.  It simply asks that you fall into it, like a daydream or a fever.
0060723513|1.0|This book claims to chronicle the true story of an American woman's physical and spiritual journey from her American home to an Australian aboriginal tribe called the Real People and ultimately to a three month journey across Australia. <br /> <br />As a piece of non-fiction, this work is defamatory and blatantly untrue. As a piece of fiction (as its publisher has now classified it), this work is ill-researched and shows grave misunderstandings of the aboriginal people of Australia and of Australia itself. Its blatant errors are too numerous to list, however I've detailed a few of the more egregious ones: a car journey from a major Australian metropolitan city to the red centre in a measly four hours, the aboriginal people she journeyed with using a camel hoof to create a sharp instrument, and a hand in the invention of fly screens. Very briefly, it would take a rocket car to make a four hour journey from any of Australia's major metropolitan cities (containing an international airport) to the red centre,  - the `hoof' of a camel is not at all like a horse's hoof but in fact closer resembles the soft padding of a dog's paw, and fly screens have been used in Australia long before Morgan dreamt of defaming it. <br /> <br />I find the most damaging aspect of this work is not the blatant errors, but the reinforcement that white people believe all indigenous cultures to be the same. The `Real People' tribe bares striking resemblance to the indigenous American cultures, right down to their names, a tool not dissimilar to the indigenous American dream catcher, and the position of one of the `Real People' as the tribe's chief. Aboriginal tribes do not have chiefs. <br /> <br />Some people will have you believe that it is not important that the author made the story up, that it is about emotion and spiritual journey. They are sadly misled, as this book is as thin in spirituality as it is in research or fact. <br /> <br />There is a book detailing aboriginal life, hardships,and a long journey. It has the added advantages of not only being a great read, but of being written by an aboriginal descended from the story's main character and it is actually true. Go and read \\"Along the Rabbit Proof Fence\\" and ignore Mutant Message Downunder, you'll thank me for it.

B0000033OZ|4.0|And with the vicious roar of Greg Lakes fuzz-bass, ELP serves notice that it was a musical force to be reckoned with. What better way to start of ELP's stunning debut disc than with the stomping, monstrous \\"The Barbarian\\" (an adaption of a Bela Bartok piece). All 3 members are giving it all they got, with breakneck tempo, instrument and genre' changes (moving freely from stomping rock to frenetic jazz-stylings at the drop of a hat for instance), firey interplay and a take no prisoners attitude.  <br /> <br />Next up is Greg Lake's \\"Take A Pebble\\", a longer, more introspective piece that would've also fit well on his former group King Crimson's debut album. Lake's impassioned and detailed vocals are buoyed by Emerson's rippling piano and Palmer's tasteful percussion atmospheres. The only thing that mars this piece is a rambling acoustic guitar section that doesn't have much of anything to do with the main body of the song, editing would've been good here.  <br /> <br />\\"Knife Edge\\" (with thematic material borrowed from Janaczek), kicks things back into high gear with Lake's clever wordplay and Emerson's fire 'n brimstone orgn assaults keeping you on the edge of your seat.  <br /> <br />\\"The Three Fates\\" is Keith Emerson's time to shine, utilizing his grand piano and a monstrous pipe organ in a harrowing ride through twisty jazz and classical stylings, his improvisational ability really comes to the fore here, something that ELP largely excelled at onstage.  <br /> <br />\\"Tank\\" is Carl Palmer's turn at the spotlight with his furious drumming levelling everything in its path and ending with Emerson's wall of synths march. <br /> <br />However, things close on a rather cheesy note with \\"Lucky Man\\". Apparently, the band's repetoire wasn't gigantic at this point, so Greg Lake, in desparation dug up a song he'd written as a teenager. Sure, it's reasonably catchy but it really sticks out like a sore thumb compared to everything else.  <br /> <br />Certainly not a perfect debut, but one that does unashamedly show both the band's strengths and weaknesses, thankfully here, the strengths far outweigh the weaknesses. <br /> <br />Very highly recommended.

I watched PHANTOM MENACE on midnight the day it opened.<br />And I fell asleep.  <br />Sure, there are dazzling special effects, but that alone doesn't make a good film.  Story and character do. Where's the conflict here?  Who's the bad guy?  Where's the good guy?<br />Oh yeah, he's that smart-ass little kid running around with that  shameful, racist caricature, Jar Jar Binks. <br />May the force be with you -- you'll need it.
B00005B36H|5.0|Since 1996's junior album, \\"Aenima,\\" Tool escaped Zoo records and frontman Maynard James Keenan formed a side project, A Perfect Circle. Rumors of Tool's breakup started to circulate, but then, in 2001, Tool return with their fourth offering, \\"Lateralus.\\" An album, which was originally entitled \\"Systema Encephale,\\" was probably the most highly anticipated release of 2001.<br /><br />The five years it took to make this album sure paid off. Every moment of it seems very well planned out, perfected and ahead of its time. If I could describe \\"Lateralus\\" in one word, it would be \\"astonishing.\\" It is heavy, yet breathtakingly melodic. Polished and soothing in places, yet it is also rigid. In addition to being Tool's most futuristic sounding record, it is also their most experimental, adventurous, and brilliantly written. Some Tool fans were displeased because the new album wasn't as aggressive as their past works. This is true; \\"Lateralus\\" is the band's most progressive piece to date, but it also has the best production. Compared to \\"Lateralus,\\" \\"Aenima\\" sounds muddy. Every musical note on \\"Lateralus\\" is crystal clear, so clear that feedback is even audible on songs like \\"Parabola.\\" And being the most progressive album has also made it Tool's prettiest and most atmospheric artwork to date. Granted, guitarist Adam Jones isn't allowed as many good riffs on this album, but he can still make crazy sound effects with his instrument.<br /><br />Plus, Maynard shows a newfound vulnerability, here. He sings, whines, mewls, and even whispers a little. Couple this with the aforementioned penetrable and gentle music, and the result is 13 very smooth and harmonic songs.<br /><br />1. The Grudge-This song begins with what sounds like a machine starting up, then the drums and guitar come aboard. The drums sometimes sound like tin drums, and the guitars begin by making a low, repetitive, humming noise. The guitars gain in volume and make this song build very well. Maynard's vocals alternate from almost whispering, to singing, to laying down a 20 second long yell. This song takes up eight and a half of the C.D.'s 79 minutes<br /><br />2. Eon Blue Apocalypse- Just an interlude with some simple guitar plucking.<br /><br />3. The Patient- I enjoy how this song goes up and down repeatedly. The guitars sometimes make almost a wah-wah noise and the drums almost sound aquatic.<br /><br />4. Mantra- A spooky sounding interlude of whales bellowing back and forth to each other.<br /><br />5. Schism- The famous lead single which is a math metal song, and is brilliant even for Tool. Adam Jones plays some complex, winding guitar notes which makes the guitar sound like it's saying \\"I know the pieces fit\\" (which is Maynard's main line in this song). The guitars occasionally veer off into stop-start riffing, but then there's a beat change and the song goes back to the beginning.<br /><br />6. Parabol- This song is basically an interlude/lead in to track seven, \\"Parabola;\\" but it's also a good song in it's own right. Soft, dreary guitar strumming and distant, echo-y vocals make it have a very dreamy feel.<br /><br />7. Parabola- A heavier song, especially heavy compared to its predecessor. This, the second single to come off of this album, has some good drumming and a couple of crunchy riffs. But Maynard doesn't yell; he sings melodically.<br /><br />8. Ticks & Leeches- It begins with a drum intro, before Maynard lets loose a yell of: \\"Suck it!\\" In this song, Maynard is a lot more pissed off than the music. Maynard continues raging throughout this song, but his yells become so distant, around the three and a half minute mark, that he could be whispering. At this time, there are some wind whooshes in addition to a soft guitar (which sounds like it's acoustic). This part of the song stops, the power chords come back, and Maynard lays down some ascending yells of: \\"I hope you choke!\\"<br /><br />9. Lateralis- Opens with what sounds like a tin sheet being shaken, beforesegueing into some \\"ner nah ner\\" guitar noise. It ends with Maynard singing: \\"Spiral down...keep going.\\" These lyrics are fitting, because the last part of this song has some winding guitar noise which makes the beat spiral downward.<br /><br />10. Disposition- A personal favorite. Soft but clear guitar strumming, feather-light hand percussion (which sounds like they could be tribal drums), and harmonic crooning make this song very soothing and suave. Maynard sings pretty much just one line throughout this song: \\"Watch the weather change,\\" and the song ends with what sounds like a ball bouncing. This would make a cool and very trippy music video, too bad it's not a single.<br /><br />11. Reflection- The beginning has a bouncy rhythm with floor toms and some soft, fading guitar strings. What sounds like an Indian woman sings a little bit before Maynard begins his vocals around the three and a half minute mark. These vocals are pushed to the background because this track is mainly an instrumental.<br /><br />12. Triad- An instrumental. It begins with ascending guitars and drums, and the rest of the song is pretty much all one speedy, churning riff.<br /><br />13. Faaip de Oiad- Following over two minutes of silence, some static and other white noise and a background drum beat begin and run throughout this song. A hysterical voice eventually comes on and talks about \\"extra terrestrial beings.\\" This voice, who was actually a person who claimed to have worked at Area 51, made a call to Art Bell's radio program in 1997. The song becomes very eerie when he says things like \\"The government knows about them.\\"<br /><br />Everybody thought\\"Aenima\\" couldn't be topped, but then Tool surprised everybody by doing so. \\"Lateralus\\" is a masterpiece. It is Tool at their pinnacle; I don't think they can top this almost indescribably beautiful work of art...but then again, I was wrong about \\"Aenima,\\" so who knows what they're capable of? The bottom line is, as of 2005, this is the best album of the new millennium, and I can't foresee anyone making a set of songs better than these in the near future.r\\" guitar noise. It ends with Maynard singing: \\"Spiral down...keep going.\\" These lyrics are fitting, because the last part of this song has some winding guitar noise which makes the beat spiral downward.  <br />10. Disposition- A personal favorite. Soft but clear guitar strumming, feather-light hand percussion (which sounds like they could be tribal drums), and harmonic crooning make this song very soothing and suave. Maynard sings pretty much just one line throughout this song: \\"Watch the weather change,\\" and the song ends with what sounds like a ball bouncing. This would make a cool and very trippy music video, too bad it's not a single. <br />11. Reflection- The beginning has a bouncy rhythm with floor toms and some soft, fading guitar strings. What sounds like an Indian woman sings a little bit before Maynard begins his vocals around the three and a half minute mark. These vocals are pushed to the background because this track is mainly an instrumental. <br />12. Triad- An instrumental. It begins with ascending guitars and drums, and the rest of the song is pretty much all one speedy, churning riff. <br />13. Faaip de Oiad- Following over two minutes of silence, some static and other white noise and a background drum beat begin and run throughout this song. A hysterical voice eventually comes on and talks about \\"extra terrestrial beings.\\" This voice, who was actually a person who claimed to have worked at Area 51, made a call to Art Bell's radio program in 1997. The song becomes very eerie when he says things like \\"The government knows about them.\\" <br />     <br />Everybody thought\\"Aenima\\" couldn't be topped, but then Tool surprised everybody by doing so. \\"Lateralus\\" is a masterpiece. It is Tool at their pinnacle; I don't think they can top this almost indescribably beautiful work of art...but then again, I was wrong about \\"Aenima,\\" so who knows what they're capable of? The bottom line is, as of 2005, this is the best album of the new millennium, and I can't foresee anyone making a set of songs better than these in the near future.

0515123447|4.0|I'm new to the Jack Reacher series but I have to say that I enjoyed this first book. I was interested in reading what other reviewers had to say: Author was charged with using the word \\"shrugged\\" too much. I never noticed, I was busy turning the pages I guess. Author was charged with using short, choppy sentences. Is that a literary offense? Because if it is, it's time to take Hemingway's work out and burn it, he having been critically lauded for years for that short, choppy style which is supposed to be very manly -- in a literary sense, I suppose. All I know is that I find old Hem's work mindnumbingly dull. At least Mr. Child keeps me awake, those choppy sentences lend a sense of urgency to the story. (Just like Earl Emerson's short chapters in 'Pyro'!) Author is charged with not being an expert on America. Neither am I and I've spent 48 out of 50 years here. Oh, and one review bemoaned the fact that somehow the author failed to realize the US has no Marines stationed in Europe, that we have no naval base there. Hm, I don't keep up with the exact locations of all US bases but I spent two years at Zaragoza Air Base, Spain, and when I was there, the US had a naval base at Rota. Author is charged with having a written a very violent book. Well. There you have me. It IS violent. If violence disturbs you, what the heck are you doing reading books in this genre in the first place? There was a great honking picture of a bloody handprint on the cover of the paperback I bought -- I would have thought that was a (you'll excuse the pun) dead giveaway as to the nature of this book. Oh, almost forgot. The author is also charged with too much coincidence in the brother/killing plot point. Stranger things happen every day -- gee, Bush got elected twice. I think THAT's stretching coincidence! <br /> <br />Yes, Jack Reacher is an anti-hero. Yes, the books has some flaws (as most every book I've ever read does). But I enjoyed the book and am looking forward to seeing Reacher's character progression in the next book. Do I think he's the next Lucas Davenport? Nope, not unless he gets a stronger sense of humor and a lot more sexy. But Reacher is verrrry interesting! <br /> <br />OK, I'm done defending the book. Now, here's the bit that bothered me: A top gun in the Treasury Dept drops out of sight and the Feds don't swarm all over looking for him when his prints come across the computer? A second Treasury Dept worker is brutally murdered in an airport and (1) it's the busy airport at Atlanta and no one sees it??? and (2) the Feds don't follow up on this either?  Still -- I was able to suspend my disbelief long enough to overlook these things, just because I wanted to see what Jack would do next.

B00005YU1O|2.0|There are a lot of very interesting ideas discussed in this movie. However, this sort of philosophical smorgasboard would be better experienced on paper, as the film doesn't really allow ample time to for these discussions to be absorbed by the viewer, especially if the viewer is not experienced in the philosophical thought process.  <br /> <br />The visuals are stunning, but can hinder one somewhat from fully understanding the ideas before the film moves on to the next idea. I found it very frustrating to try to fully comprehend certain ideas presented, only to be bombarded with even more equally intense dialogue and visuals.  <br /> <br />The ideas presented are certainly fascinating, and are framed with some of the most beautiful visuals I've ever seen in a film, but the combination of the two can be quite overwhelming. I'd prefer to read a script, if one exists, and take my time contemplating these usually complex philosophical meanderings. Film is simply not a suitable medium, unless the viewer is already familiar with the ideas presented.

B0009K7RES|4.0|This is a slightly tricky release to review.  On one hand, if you're a big fan of Mark's solo work like myself; you're going to really dig this EP.  I still play Shangri-La (the album which 7 of these songs came from) regularly and to hear these tunes in a \\"live\\" setting is a refreshing change.  However, if you are new to Mr. Knopfler, you'd be better off picking up his Shangri-la album. <br /> <br />On to the actual content- the songs here are remarkably faithful to their original versions.  While that is an impressive feat, the music here is almost too close to it's original form.  The sound quality is fantastic, with just enough ambience to let you know that this was recorded live.  Mark himself said much of the Shangri-La album was recorded in a live setting, so like I already said- don't expect too much variation here.    <br /> <br />There are three songs that stand out to me as being `better' than the original album cuts.  The opening \\"Trawlerman's Song\\" really benefits from Mark's excellent guitar tone cutting through a little louder and clearer than on the Shangri-La album.  Mark gives a great vocal performance on \\"Song for Sonny Liston\\"- you can almost hear him smirking as he delivers the lyrics... very nice.  Last but not least, \\"Donegan's Gone\\" manages to swing even better than the album cut- it just really comes to life here.  It's something you have to hear to understand. <br /> <br />All things considered, I really dig this release.  Excellent sound quality, great performances and a really strong vocal and guitar performance from Mark.  The rest of the band sounds great as well, with the drums really coming through nicely with this live mix.  I really wish this was a full album release rather than an EP (it's just too short), but hopefully Mark is saving the full live experience for an upcoming live album/dvd. <br /> <br />If you loved Shangri-La, buy this EP.  If you're new to Mark, check out Shangri-La or any of Mark's other solo albums first (I strongly recommend Sailing to Philadelphia).

0060977493|5.0|I have a very hard time finding writers and novels that move me enough to keep me reading past page 50.  I have picked up countless works of fiction suggested to me by like minded friends who's opinions I value greatly, only to become bored, dissatsified and disconnected within the first few chapters and abandoning the story altogether.  I stumbled across this book in an airport bookstore and instantly became enraptured with the language and immersed in the story of these lovely children. However, this book is not for everyone.  I believe that you must be able to think like the author in order to enjoy their writing.  I actually write in this lyrical/prose fashion myself so, when I find that rare author who sees the world in the way that I do,  I become an instant fan.  If you prefer plot driven fiction told in a straight forward fashion, this book is not for you.  If however, you enjoy losing yourself in a world of metaphor and simile, if you find the idea of a writer who employs all of their senses to draw you into their world an exciting prospect, then pick up this wonderful novel.   It really is a treat.

It's good, but nothing to hurry and buy kind of score.  It has it's moments, like Corynorhinus, which is a dark and beautiful piece.  I would seriously buy the cd just for this cue alone. I think that hurt the score rather then helped.  My biggest gripe with this score is that it drags and doesn't connect throughout.  Each piece is just kinda there.  It also has no climax at all, which bothers me a little.  But overall, i'd give the score a 3.5, but not a 4.  It's not a great score, but it's not a bad score either.  If you can find a way to hear Corynorhinus, do it and you will know why that piece is worth buying the whole score. I hope this helps.

B0009NSE1K|5.0|The musical perfection continues with Robot Hive / Exodus! You can never go wrong with a Clutch record. They not only continue to mature, but evolve each time they hit the studio. They bring a new definition to the phrase \\"the more things change, the more they stay the same.\\" That is what Clutch does. The theme and music may change with each new record, but the proverbial Clutch sound is always intact. From the angry, the futuristic, the Civil War past, the jamming, the instrumental side band,  the fury of pure rock and roll, the live show, the rarities,  and the stories of the Blast Tyrant and the Worm Drink, they now bring you the corruption of the robot church and its cleansing by the new robot messenger. RH/E brings pure rock and roll with the elements of groove, funk, blues, and jazz all mixed into one beautiful work of art. One minute heavy, another groovy, but all catchy and %100 Clutch.   <br />  <br />      This is an excellent follow-up to Blast Tyrant. The fab 4 of Neil Fallon, Tim Sult, Dan Maines, and Jean Paul Gaster is now 5 strong with new keyboardist Mick Schauer joining the fold. The keyboards mixed with the groove of the bass and drums really does enhance the already great tunes and even sounds well with the great guitar playing of Sult. The production here is great and the artwork is definitely amazing. For those of you who have not been keeping your CD's in their cases for the last ten years just might want to keep this CD in this case, because the artwork really adds to the charm of the music the disc spins for its listeners. Gravel Road and the cover of Howlin' Wolf's Who's Been Talking? are very pleasant surprises to the album, showing off the musical talents of the band.  <br />  <br />      To those long-dead Clutch fans who stopped listening to Clutch at the release of The Elephant Riders just because they are \\"no longer angry\\" are really missing out on a life-pleasing rock and roll experience of the mature and multi-talented Clutchof the present. To those skeptical due to the increased religious references in the lyrics should not take them at face value. Long time Clutch fans are well aware of the vagueness ever present in Fallon's words, knowing full well they could have hundreds of different meanings. Take what you will from them and do not let that ruin your listening enjoyment. These lyrics are pure Clutch all the way. Fallon has always been a great story teller and let these stories tuck you into bed and kiss you goodnight after they kick your a-- and make you bob your head and dance a jig.  <br />  <br />      Once you have picked up this CD you need to go hear these songs played live because I cannot stress enough the raw power of a Clutch live show. If you are skeptical in joining Clutch's fanatical fanbase, then seeing them live will definitely convince you. This is not an MTV band! This is not a TRL band! This is rock and roll in its purist form. The self-titled seems will always be my favorite, but Neil says it best, \\"Get your evolution on!\\" <br />

B0009A1AS2|5.0|My opinion might be biased. I like every single song Dream Theater has ever written, and I'm finding this album to be no exception. <br /> <br />As with every Dream Theater album, the first few listens had me thinking, \\"What the heck?\\" This is because we all put in a new CD in the player with certain expectations of what it should be, and we anxiously listen, waiting for the \\"cool parts,\\" which basically means the parts that sound like previous DT material. Even long-time Dream Theater fans like myself do this, even though experience should have taught me that it takes many listens before the composition becomes even the slightest bit understood. <br /> <br />The lesson: Relax. Quit waiting for the cool parts and let yourself absorb it slowly. This disc is rather sparse on crunchy riffs, flying solos, and soaring harmonies, so some patience is required. The entertainment value of Octavarium is not intense and immediate, but I assure you it is there. Dream Theater has always been critisized for being too eager to show off their skills, so they've taken a minimalist approach and they're aiming to impress with their songwriting and composition skills. With this album, DT has proven that they're not wankers, and that they don't need to play entirely in 64th notes to be entertaining.
B00005QDW5|4.0|...Pink Floyd's actual albums (especially those contained within the \\"Golden Era\\" - Meddle, Dark Side, Wish, Animals and Wall) are meant to be heard as albums in themselves, and although this comprehensive collection offers a good glance at the band's material, trouble is encountered in making the tracks flow at anything but an obdurate rate. B0002Z0EYK|5.0|All those who have adored the Illiad as I have over many years can readily find the shortcomings in Peterson's \\"Troy\\" when compared to the source material. Comparisons between the Illiad and \\"Troy\\" are really not productive.  This is a film made in 21st century USA, financed by investors seeking a return on capital invested.  They have a right to that return, having taken the risk attendant to the production, beset by hurricanes, competitors, injuries and the like.  <br /> <br />In contrast, the Illiad was created by one or more authors in pre-Homeric times and recorded in Homeric times.  I would encourage readers of this review to examine Julian Jaynes' \\"The Origin of Conciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind\\" as a means of understanding the mindset of pre-Homeric humans. The loss of the gods as external impetus in \\"Troy\\" seems to be in the service of accommodating a modern, uninitiated audience. This is the big audience, and they buy a lot of tickets and DVD's.  I much prefer Isabella Rosselini as a transcendant Athena in \\"The Odyssey\\" (1998 Konchalovsky) to a complete lack of Olympian intervention in the affairs of humans, but that is not available to us here.  Keep in mind that there is no effort on the part of the director or screenwriters to present this film as \\"The Illiad.\\" <br /> <br />What happened instead during the filming of this very commendable, but not flawless film was the transformation of one actor from a cool, funny guy who has a versatile range (Brad Pitt, as Achilles) to someone who deserves comparisons to Brando and Burton - keep going.  After watching this film many times I feel prepared to offer this:  After desecrating the temple of Apollo, the Burtonish delivery is \\"Go home Prince of Troy - etc .. it is too early in the day for killing princes.\\"  And further - regard the scene after Patroklus is dead, and Eudorus is tasked with delivering that message.  Look at the range of emotions that Pitt displays in one concise scene - emerging from his tent very satisfied with his concubine Briseis (faithful to the source material) confronting the idea that his men were deployed against his command - then realizing in one startling moment of revelation - that his hubris has brought disaster to Patroklus (cousin - lover, whatever the relationship as we would describe it today) - his intime, his adoptive brother, the source of his \\"unmanly grief\\" as described in the source material, as well as to the whole nascent Greek nation. The emotions playing across Pitt's face tell everything there is to know about his mastery of the craft of acting. Brando would be envious of the native cunning in this portrayal of what Pitt has interpreted as a complex and tragic hero.  Nothing defines the classics as much as that simple trajectory in one's life events as those which bring Achilles to glory and then to his doom, on the wings of the selfsame impulse. Thus is the tragedy of heros wrought .. <br /> <br />On top of that, the battle scenes are tremendous, not only in concept but in execution.  Pitt and Eric Bana were extraordinary, as the fight choreographer's tools, in conveying the ferocity of the fights that might have taken place beneath the the walls of Troy.   <br /> <br />The mass battles are scarily realistic (a few CG ship scenes notwithstanding) and speak of nothing more than the excess capacity found in many societies in the form of young men with nothing better to do than to kill each other in artful ways, once given the chance.  <br /> <br />But Pitt and Bana create a beautiful ballet of slaughter in their desire to eliminate each other.  Nevermind that in the Illiad, Hector has to be tricked into standing his ground against Achilles - in this version he is given a nobler and very sad end - saying goodbye to brother, father, wife and child before facing his certain death at the hands of a superior adversary. There are not many more poignant scenes than Hector \\"leaving youth and manhood behind\\" as he isunstrung by the \\"swift footed Achilles\\"  who is clearly in a league of his own as fighter and indeed as a force of nature, as another reviewer has opined in this same forum.  <br /> <br />The extraordinary sadness and beauty of this film, in this reviewer's opinion, has given Pitt a vehicle that he may not have anticipated as having the degree of influence over his life as he might have anticipated.  Pitt seems like a very seasoned  spirit, as evidenced in his handling of the suffering attendant to his great fame and fortune, and as displayed in his recent interview with Diane Sawyer.    <br /> <br />Pitt's apparently intuitive connection with the trajectory of Achilles' fame and suffering parallels his own trajectory in the public eye, in this reviewer's opinion.  15 minutes will not really be the measure of this large spirited man who is only now plumbing the depths of what he might be able to show us of the human condition.   <br /> <br />Let us only hope that he finds material as challenging as \\"Troy\\" and that he is able to bring to us the goofy and sweet person that his ex-wife claims him to be in her accounts of him.  Check out \\"Johnny Suede\\" if you really need convincing.  Very Goofy - regards - DS <br /> <br />
078693123X|5.0|For me, this is the book that started it all. The Crystal Shard, with all of its heroics, never grasped me in the same way. Homeland covers the birth and the treacherous upbringing of the world's favorite dark elf - Drizzt Do'Urden.    Salvatore's writing shines here; it's charming, fun, and quick. His characters clash with deviousness and purity. Drizzt is, throughout, tortured by his morals. He can only console in Guenhwyvar, his cat.    There are battles between the houses of Menzoberranzan, clashes with dwarves, and the slaughtering of surface elves.     Even with their vileness, Drizzt still has feelings for many of his family members. He doesn't want to disappoint them, but what they ask of him is too much. Even the reader will find many characters to like here, despite their malevolence.    For Forgotten Realms fans, Homeland is a must. For Salvatore fans, it is a must. Even general fantasy fans will find much to enjoy here.

0062502182|3.0|This was a highly recommended book in my class. Inspirational, beautifully written, thoughtful, enchanting. Well, I guess I was just a little bit disappointed then. I was expecting a lot and instead, all I got was a half-empty glass. There are definitely moments in this book that make you wonder why the author doesn't write as eloquently on other instances that desperately require them. And it's just a terrible shame because the alchemist does have something special about it. The problem is that the author chops down on details that need to be written, on words that need to be said and moments that should have been given more time. It is because of this that some things come out a bit flat and unconvincing for me. To the author's credit, I did breeze through this book like it was a magazine. It was such an easy read from start to finish. Then again, maybe it's because of the size of the text and the blatant use of double spacing to give volume to a very slim book. But hey, if I'm being too critical, it's only because I wanted the story to be so much more. The premise was strong and I really felt that I could connect with the characters and the world after only a couple of pages. But everything is so half-baked and unfinished, it feels like I'm only reading an overview of the story instead getting of the real deal. Ah, well, at the very least, this book is worth a read if you're in a plane or waiting for the school bus to arrive. Yeah, that's probably the right amount of time to finish this book.

0765348780|5.0|Some people love him, some people hate him: Steven Erikson, author of Malazan. Me? Well, I like him. Here's why:    Gardens of the Moon doesn't waste any time. The prologue and first chapter sets the stage a bit - a little bit. The second chapter throws the reader headfirst into a steaming war. I won't bother to explain it.    This is the pitfall for many readers; Erikson explains little of the past and instead pushes the story forward. If one can just let go and be enthralled, this book will be a thrilling read. If not, this book will be a boring, backtracking trudge.    It depends on the reader. Let go and have a good time. If you can't do that, this book isn't for you.    Gardens of the Moon has some of the craziest battles ever seen in fantasy. Gods battle gods. Demigods battle demigods. Mortals battle mortals. Characters spout delightfully pulpy philosophy as these wars are waged.     Enjoy it or criticize it. That's your prerogative.

B0000089FS|4.0|After having a number of lackluster and uninspired releases through the 1980s, with perhaps the lowest point being the 1986 release of \\"Leather Jackets,\\" Elton John started a turnaround in quality and artistry that was evident on this album, and would achieve albums such as \\"The One\\" and \\"Made in England\\" in the 90s.  While this album had much less quality and artistry than Elton's 70s albums, loyal fans were gratified to see that Elton could still write and sing good songs.<br /><br />Elton's rediscovered enthusiasm shows in \\"Town of Plenty.\\"  Admittedly this song is one of the lesser songs on this CD; the words are corny and simple, and the music is relatively simple.  However, Elton's voice sounds refreshed and clear, and the production is much improved over \\"Leather Jackets.\\"  This simple song is little indication of the music that comes later on this CD.<br /><br />The second song also has relatively simple words, though more complex and inspired than the words of the first song.  However, Elton's music in \\"A Word in Spanish\\" contains a flavor of that sound that made Elton John great in years gone by.  This song was also the longest song on the original CD at 4:39 long.  This mellow love song peaked at #19 on the charts in 1988.  With the improvement over the first song, this song promised that this CD held even better songs.<br /><br />Elton and his band get bombastic on \\"Mona Lisas and Mad Hatters (Part Two).\\"  The original song was a mellow and harmonious creation on \\"Honky Chateau.\\"  This version is funky and bouncy, and far from being mellow.  While I am tempted to compare this song with some of the worst from \\"Leather Jackets,\\" the comparison would be wrong.  This song has fun with the overblown style, and keeps the enthusiasm evinced from the first song.  This song also makes an excellent stylistic introduction to the next song.<br /><br />The next song is the best indication that Elton had created a very listenable album.  \\"I Don't Wanna Go on with You Like That\\" had a sharp musical production with a snappy beat that maintained the pace and power of the three previous songs.  This #2 charting song had good lyrics and even better music to make this song one of the best created by the Elton John-Bernie Taupin team in a long time, and gave fans the opportunity to rejoice that the duo still had this kind of music to give the world.<br /><br />Then comes a song that I think belongs in the portfolio of some of the best Elton John ballads.  In \\"Japanese Hands\\" Bernie Taupin finally created lyrics to match some of his best from the era that yielded \\"Madman Across the Water\\" and \\"Don't Shoot Me I'm Only the Piano Player.\\"  Elton matched those words with lovely music and a singing style that was heard on Elton's \\"Live in Australia with the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra\\" and would be later heard on \\"Songs from the West Coast.\\"  This beautiful ballad is one of my personal favorites on this CD.<br /><br />The next song is a change of pace.  \\"Goodbye Marlon Brando\\" has a beat that is even faster than the first songs on the CD.  This song reminds me of Billy Joel, especially \\"We Didn't Start the Fire.\\"  The song is less ambitious than the Billy Joel song, confining itself to summarizing the 80s, and perhaps the 70s to a certain degree.  The song does say goodbye to a lot of things I remember from the 1980s.  This song is interesting and fast, and perhaps slightly better than the average song on this CD.<br /><br />The next three songs combined form a weak spot in this CD.  \\"The Camera Never Lies\\" is the rock version of those country songs that deal with the bad things that happen in life.  In this case the subject is infidelity.  While the music and the words are less than inspired, the song is okay and is an average song for this CD.  This CD goes from an average song to a less than average song.  \\"Heavy Traffic\\" contains a few moments of interest, but otherwise the song is one of the weaker songs on this CD and sounds more likeElton on cruise control.  The following song lyrically seems intended to be sympathetic to women who get stuck with too many children and a loser husband, but \\"Poor Cow\\" never fulfills the promise of the lyrics, and is another that is much less than average.<br /><br />This CD originally finished with another lovely ballad, \\"Since God Invented Girls.\\"  This song contains a tribute to Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys.  The backing vocals enhance the feeling of the tribute by adopting the harmonious style of the Beach Boys.  This song joins \\"Japanese Hands\\" as being another of my favorite songs on this CD.<br /><br />In addition to the original ten songs, this version contains four bonus tracks that add little to the original production, but do give a listener a bit more bang for the musical buck.<br /><br />This album starts with a promising title.  This CD was not quite the \\"strike back\\" that the title promised.  However, there are enough good songs on this CD to make this CD a good improvement over the previous original album, and fans a few years later would recognize that this album marked a turn for the better for Elton John and Bernie Taupin, now going by the single name Taupin.  In a few short years Elton John would receive more awards and nominations than he had received in his career to this point, and while the future Rock and Roll Hall of Fame member may have fallen short in striking back with this CD, perhaps this CD was just the beginning of a strike that is pushing its way into two decades.unds more like Elton on cruise control.  The following song lyrically seems intended to be sympathetic to women who get stuck with too many children and a loser husband, but \\"Poor Cow\\" never fulfills the promise of the lyrics, and is another that is much less than average. <br /> <br />This CD originally finished with another lovely ballad, \\"Since God Invented Girls.\\"  This song contains a tribute to Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys.  The backing vocals enhance the feeling of the tribute by adopting the harmonious style of the Beach Boys.  This song joins \\"Japanese Hands\\" as being another of my favorite songs on this CD. <br /> <br />In addition to the original ten songs, this version contains four bonus tracks that add little to the original production, but do give a listener a bit more bang for the musical buck. <br /> <br />This album starts with a promising title.  This CD was not quite the \\"strike back\\" that the title promised.  However, there are enough good songs on this CD to make this CD a good improvement over the previous original album, and fans a few years later would recognize that this album marked a turn for the better for Elton John and Bernie Taupin, now going by the single name Taupin.  In a few short years Elton John would receive more awards and nominations than he had received in his career to this point, and while the future Rock and Roll Hall of Fame member may have fallen short in striking back with this CD, perhaps this CD was just the beginning of a strike that is pushing its way into two decades. <br />
B00008H2LB|5.0|Meteora is Linkin Park's sophomore album and the follow-up to the multi-platinum album Hybrid Theory.  And like Hybrid Theory, any Linkin Park fan owes it to themselves to pick up this album.  If you enjoyed Hybrid Theory, chances are you will enjoy Meteora as well.    The one thing that stands out about the CD is that is sounds a lot different than Hybrid Theory.  Meteora is the evolution of Linkin Park.  They've put together an album that sets itself apart from Hybrid Theory, instead of just being a tad bit better but sounding the same.  A lot of themes appear throughout the album, such as acoustic samples and even some piano and violin.  But don't worry: the album still rocks above everything else.    Here's a rundown of the songs:    Foreword - nifty little intro that goes right into the first song.  Can't really rate it, since it's not a song lol    Don't Stay - This song could be described as an evolution of One Step Closer.  A really hard-hitting rock song from start to finish, with some nice scratching from Mr. Hahn. (5 out of 5)    Somewhere I Belong - Meteora's top single and one of my favorites off the album.  A very different sounding song than what LP's done in the past, probably due to the acoustic sampling.  Some classic lyrics from both Mike and Chester. (5 out of 5)    Lying From You - This song begins with some nifty violin sampling.  A really heavy song with some catchy lyrics. (5 out of 5)    Hit The Floor - Another one of those songs that sounds really different from Hybrid Theory, but in a good way.  Not a favorite but it's a pretty tight song though. (4 out of 5)    Easier To Run - Kinda like Hit The Floor, it's not a favorite but not a bad song either.  Very thoughtful lyrics in this one. (4 out of 5)    Faint - This song rocks.  Very fast-paced song with catchy violin sampling and killer guitar.  Definitely one of my favorites. (5 out of 5)    Figure.09 - Another hard-hitting rock song, with excellent rapping from Mike.  Nice DJ work too. (5out of 5)    Breaking The Habit - This song is a very unique song, mainly due to the violin players in the background.  Very soothing song with light guitar combined with some DJ mixing from Mr. Hahn.  Great singing from Chester. (5 out of 5)    From The Inside - Kinda similar to Somewhere I Belong.  One of my favorites.  Both Chester and Mike are awesome on this song. (5 out of 5)    Nobody's Listening - This track shares a lot of similarities to High Voltage off Hybrid theory (special edition) in the fact that it's pretty much a straight-up hip hop track.  I love the Japanese flute sample, it makes this song stand out a lot.  Great rhymes from Mike, accompanied by Chester singing in the refrain. (5 out of 5)    Session - Some people will recognize this track from The Matrix Reloaded soundtrack.  Like Cure For The Itch on Hybrid Theory, Session is an instrumental track with no words.  Put together mainly by Mike with some added touches from the rest of the band.  No words, but it's a pretty tight track. (5 out of 5)    Numb - Probably my favorite song off Meteora.  Great piano from Mike, and some soulful singing from Chester. (It's the Soulful Chaz!)  This song rocks, pure and simple. (5 out of 5)    Like I said about Hybrid Theory, this is one of those CDs that all Linkin Park fans should have in their collection.  If you don't have it, get it!  You'll treasure it forever.

B000002H2H|5.0|I say this as I finish watching their documentary \\"Some Kind of Monster\\". And I think, judging by the place the band is in today, it would be hard to see them reaching the creative heights attained in this album. There is just so much internal politics and contention going on inside the band that I believe they should've broken up long before st. anger was released. But I guess it's all about the money now and they would have to be fricking stupid to break up something that generates so much revenue from hardcore fans (myself included). Anyway, Ride the Lightning is without a doubt my personal favorite not only because it was the first metallica record I've ever owned but because repeat listenings make the songs more complex than they really seem. Yeah, this album deals with situations of death and decay but words are merely the tip of the iceberg. There are actually layers to the songs that one will notice only after they take root in your head. From the thunderous (how suiting) riffs to the pounding drum beats, I swear this album is anything but mundane. The first song that comes to mind would be \\"for whom the bell tolls\\". Just terrific on all four fronts, an instance where everything really came together. This is what you get when you have all four guys on the same page. But now, as the war of egos crash down on James and Lars, Metallica would be hardpressed to go back to the very foundations that made them famous in the first place. I would say that it is the discord, the strife, the damn politics that is making the band deteriorate into ordinary rockers, a label that would be okay if you were a band like um, say, linkin park but is not okay if you are metallica. I may be quoting Alice on this but I say the band's down in a hole. And it looks like they're going to need more than just a shovel to dig themselves out. They need four.
B00003CXXO|4.0|This movie is pleasant to watch. It is different from the other american sci-fi movies, which have a lot of horror mixed in them. \\"A.I.\\" didn't horrify me (unlike \\"Event Horizon\\", for example, which is a mixture of sci-fi and horror). The main character (David) is a polite, although weird, robotic child. He is cute, but his laughter is sudden and strange and frightening.<br /><br />The story begins in the house of the family which bought David. The problem is that David does some things that are potentially dangerous (comes at midnight to his mother's bed with a scissor in hand; almost drowns a real child). That is why he is abandoned by the mother, in a dark forest. And he almost gets destroyed in a Flesh Fair. It is a show where robotic humanoids are being destroyed, for the enjoyment of the people. If you have seen \\"The running man\\" with Arnold Schwarzenegger, the Flesh Fair is very similar. There he meets Gigolo Joe - a robotic lover, whose character may be appealing to adults.<br />The end of the movie is pessimistic, as it is just another apocalyptic prediction that life on earth will cease to exist in the future. The end is not about intelligence at all, but rather it feels like a fairytale about a child that lost his mommie.<br /><br />I liked the special effects - the images of semi-human, semi-robotic faces are dazzling. But the movie's storyline didn't seem too deep for me. Perhaps the movie is more intriguing for small children.
